English:
**In Ukraine, Russian soldiers created the biggest minefield in the world.** 

Its area is nearly 250,000 square kilometers – more than the territory of the United Kingdom or Romania. This way, Russians are trying to kill as many civilians in Ukraine as possible because it is civilians who most often step on landmines. Landmines not only hinder people's transportation but also cause severe problems for agriculture, which remains one of the main sectors of Ukraine's economy. The experts estimate it will take at least ten years to demine Ukraine. 

Russia is a terrorist state that must be stopped. It is necessary to strengthen economic sanctions against Russians and provide Ukraine with more weapons.

Visual author: Iryna Zarubina

**The West must get rid of the guilt complex toward Russians.**

Russian propaganda narratives about insufficient respect for Russians after the collapse of the USSR remain popular in a number of EU countries. Europeans think that if they respected Russians more, then Russians would not have started a war against the Western world by attacking Ukraine. Here a logical question arises: why should Russia be respected? For 30 years of independence, Russians have not created decent living conditions for themselves, although they have considerable deposits of natural resources. Russians failed to convince the world that their values and way of life were worth emulating. Drunkenness, aggression, domestic violence, disregard for human rights, and intolerance: this is Russia’s legacy over the past 30 years. 

The Russians came to kill Ukrainians only because they do not like Ukraine's European integration. Russians believe that they can prevent an independent country from developing as it sees fit. People who commit such actions do not deserve respect, only condemnation and punishment.

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**Russia intentionally destroys Ukraine’s cultural heritage.**

The UN estimates that in more than six months of the war, Russians damaged 199 cultural objects in 12 Ukrainian regions. Russian soldiers are purposefully shelling objects of cultural heritage throughout Ukraine. In early May, the Russian army deliberately fired a missile at the museum in the Kharkiv region dedicated to the outstanding thinker and philosopher Hryhoriy Skovoroda. Russian invaders are looting museums in the temporarily occupied territories. In particular, valuable collections were taken to Russia and occupied Crimea from the museums of Mariupol and Melitopol. More than 15,000 pieces were stolen from museum exhibits in the Kherson region alone. The looting of Ukrainian museums and cultural institutions is a large-scale Russian crime. Destroyed landmarks are lost forever, and stolen unique artifacts may never return. Just imagine the looted Louvre or the bombed Colosseum. 

If Russians are not stopped in Ukraine, they will destroy and loot cultural heritage worldwide. 

Visual author: Khrystyna Valko

**The art world supports Ukraine in this war.**

Ukrainians are now a nation of heroes. They are skillful warriors, tireless volunteers, and highly efficient utility workers. Ukraine’s fight for independence during Russia’s energy terror found a representation in the works of the DC studios. Their comic book series “Stormwatch” now has a new superhero, Ukrainian Pavlo the Core Stupka. He is 52 but looks 16; the superhero is a “living nuclear generator” and can fly. This creative decision is quite fitting, given that Ukrainians see the character as a direct representation of their contemporary superheroes. Air defense operators are making the most of the insufficiently powerful air defense system, and Ukrainian energy engineers are repairing destroyed networks around the clock. Ukraine is making every effort to expel Russians from Ukrainian land. 

Unfortunately, Ukrainian superheroes are paying for freedom with their lives. Do not forget to support Ukraine! According to the laws of all genres, good must defeat evil! 

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**Ukrainians celebrate the liberation of every village and town, but they are also anxious about it.**

Every place Russian soldiers have been to turns into a mass grave or a torture site. Bucha, Irpin, Izyum, Lyman, Kherson. The Russian army tortures, kills, and illegally deports Ukrainians and their children to Russia. Ukrainians sing the national anthem and hug Ukrainian soldiers. They also prepare to testify against the Russian crimes, to cope with the consequences of the Russian occupation, and to learn about the tragic fate of relatives and friends. All Russians, from politicians and generals to soldiers and ordinary citizens who support the war, must be held responsible for what they committed in Ukraine. 

Support Ukraine’s victory and a fair trial of the aggressors! If the evil remains unpunished, it will return with double force. 

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**The Russian culture has lost touch with the contemporary world a long time ago.**

The works of Tolstoy, Dostoyevsky, Lermontov, and Pushkin still influence the perception of modern Russia by educated foreigners. Yet classic Russian literature glorifies and promotes the trends of the blossoming empires and dictatorships: endless wars, disregard for human rights, and sexism. Many Russians continue to use the narratives of their classics. Set expressions like "If he hits you, it means he loves you," "A woman's place in the kitchen," and "Great Russian people" are still popular in the Russian Federation. For ten months, Russians remain content with Putin's decision to "wage war against the collective West." It is way more convenient for them to believe that Russia could not build a prosperous state because it has been hindered by an external enemy who does not understand all the "mystery of the Russian soul" and seeks to destroy Russia. The truth is, Russian failures are due to their unwillingness to live in the modern world. They no longer create masterpieces that the world admires and are not trendsetters in art. 

Leave the "great Russian culture" on the pages of history textbooks and perceive Russians as they are: war supporters and enemies of the Western world. 

Visual author: Anastasiia Hlivinska

**The war makes people less tolerant.**

It is both physically and mentally exhausting. People experience grief, fear, fatigue, and intense anxiety. The influx of emotions prompts some people to seek a scapegoat to release negativity. As the war drags on, the stress level increases, and the ability to understand the opinions, decisions, and needs of others decreases. Ukrainian and Western societies might observe these processes right now. Those who remained in Ukraine and residents of other countries perceive the Ukrainians who went abroad as the lucky ones. 
The general level of dissatisfaction and aggression increases. Russians reinforce the manifestations of such human emotions through their informational and psychological operations. War is a difficult time. But if most people keep supporting and not condemning others, Putin and Russia will never win. In addition, emotionally mature and resilient people will rebuild their lives faster after the war. 

As the famous Ukrainian poet Lina Kostenko said, “There is so much grief in the world, so people, let’s be mutually beautiful!”

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**Despite the crumbled infrastructure, Ukrainians rejoice to be free from the Russian occupation.**

One of the vivid examples is the liberated Kherson, a regional capital in the south of Ukraine famous for its watermelons, the nearest administrative center to Crimea. Kherson has been under Russian occupation since March 2022. The Russians demanded submission from the Khersonians. Those who refused to cooperate with occupiers were often tortured, killed, and had their relatives kidnapped. After the city's liberation, experts identify bodies found in dozens of mass graves, just like in Bucha and the Kharkiv region. When the Russians were retreating from the city, they destroyed many critical infrastructure facilities. Despite so much grief, the people of Kherson are still happy that they once again live at the Ukrainian territory. People are digging up Ukrainian flags buried in the ground during the occupation and tearing down Russian propaganda posters. The arrival of Ukrainian troops for them meant the end of fear and the prohibition of a free life. Residents of Kherson stand in queues for hours at Ukrainian supermarkets and volunteer hubs, yet, they rejoice at Ukrainian goods and aid. 

Ukrainians are strong people, but without the support of the world, they will not be able to manage the consequences of the Russian invasion. Stay with Ukraine till its victory!

Visual author: Khrystyna Valko

**The Russian war shows the fundamental difference between Ukrainians and Russians.**

Russians are used to having the "tsar-ruler" decide everything for them. He must give them something, provide them with comfort, and tell them what to do. Russia destroys Ukraine's energy infrastructure, counting on Ukrainians to demand that Ukraine's president immediately brings back all benefits of the civilization. The Russian logic presumes sitting down at the negotiating table and ceding territories to Russia. It will give Russia time to recover and start a new war. Building a new empire is the cherished dream of Russia's dictatorial regime. Instead, Ukrainians have always decided everything at the community level. So now, the Ukrainian community agrees that it would rather give up the comfort to preserve their country's independence. Ukraine's leadership must execute this will. Ukrainians do not expect the authorities to magically restore the country's full energy supply. Business owners and communities buy generators and Starlinks at their own expense. Ukrainians share life hacks on how to survive without electricity, water, and heat. They help those in difficult circumstances and do not expect reimbursement from the state budget. They know state funds should primarily go toward Ukraine's Armed Forces. 

Ukrainians show the world that democracy and freedom are more important than a comfortable life. Help Ukraine stand against the war with Russia!

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**Temporarily displaced Ukrainians work instead of merely "relying on social assistance"** — statistical data from early November 2022 proves it.

For example, 650,000 temporarily displaced Ukrainians in Poland are already employed. About 46,000 people found jobs in the Netherlands, which is more than 80% of Ukrainians who fled to this country because of the Russian war. More than 40% of Ukrainian refugees in Great Britain also have jobs. Ukrainians are not "a burden to the budget of Western countries," as Russian propaganda claims. On the contrary, they help the European economy grow. The language barrier is the main obstacle for many Ukrainians who want to work in a new country. But over time, this issue dissolves, and temporary migrants are increasingly covering the deficit in the labor market of many EU countries. 

The war will end, and many Ukrainians will return home, but until then, they will support the economies of Western countries. Support Ukrainians until Russia finally loses its war. Ukrainians will thank you with all their hearts!

**Ukrainian companies are successfully entering the Western market.**

The Russian war significantly weakens Ukraine's economy and forces some Ukrainian companies to look for new business opportunities. A survey of representatives of small and medium-sized businesses by the European Business Association showed that 30% of respondents plan to export goods and services abroad. Some companies are already opening their offices there. For example, the private Ukrainian postal operator Nova Poshta (New Post) opened its branches in Poland. The popular Ukrainian fast-food chain "Lviv Croissant" also expanded its network to Poland. Dozens of IT companies are launching operations in Europe and the U.S. Ukrainians are experts in customer service and high-quality goods and services. 

Buy from Ukrainians – not only will you support Ukraine's economy in a difficult time, but you will also help withstand a brutal war with Russia. 

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**The alive Ukrainians are as alive as ever.**

Despite the war, people in Ukraine try to joke, enjoy life, and stay optimistic. While the Russian military hits Ukrainian cities with missiles, the residents of these very cities hide in bomb shelters and mock their enemies' ineptness. Ukrainian social media are full of hundreds of jokes and memes about the war. Kyiv residents began jokingly preparing for a mass orgy in response to the nuclear threats. In addition to the protective reaction of the human psyche to critical stress, Ukrainians understand that every day can be their last. Therefore, they share sentimental stories from their childhood, declare their love, and show amusing photos of their children. Many people started to do what they always dreamed of, got a dog or a cat, and made sure to spend more time with friends and relatives. Daily risk and constant struggle on the verge of life and death force people to reevaluate and stop postponing life. Ukrainians will feel the greatest joy on the victory day when Russia answers for the crimes it committed. 

Support Ukraine and help bring this victory closer!

Visual author: Khrystyna Valko

**Russia can use the Orthodox Church for subversive activity in Europe.**

Over the past five years, the Russian Orthodox Church has been purchasing real estate in the West. In particular, it bought properties in Norway: some are located near the Haakonsvern military bases, and some – in Kirkenes, a few kilometers from the border with Russia. The purposes, besides the religious ones, for the Russian priests to use this real estate remain unknown. In Ukraine, for example, the Russian Orthodox churches stored Russian weapons and hid militants before the full-scale war. Many priests cooperated with the occupiers and assisted them. Since the beginning of the full-scale war, the Security Service of Ukraine has opened 23 criminal proceedings against the priests of the Russian Orthodox Church in Ukraine. Charges range from classic intelligence gathering to helping Russians adjust their artillery strikes on Ukraine. The head of the Russian Orthodox Church, Patriarch Kirill, openly supports the war against Ukraine.

Let's keep in mind that the Russian church is the provider of Putin's regime. 

Visual author: Anastasiia Hlivinska

**Russia changed the Ukrainian way of life forever.**

On February 24, Russians divided Ukrainians into those who stayed in Ukraine and those who left the country. Both groups are now trying to adapt to the new realities of life. They must survive, provide for a family in a new country, educate children, and take care of their mental health. Ukrainians want to return to normal, pre-war life. However, this will never happen because of Russia. After major wars, nations recover for at least two subsequent generations. Economic recovery takes years. The cruel and completely senseless war that Russians unleashed on the territory of Ukraine forces Ukrainians to pay a high price for the preservation and restoration of life later. Russia made the wrong conclusions after the end of the Second World War. Because of Russians, Ukrainians, together with the rest of the world, are experiencing a war-provoked crisis. Russia must be punished for crimes against humanity and pay reparations. 

Support Ukraine and bring Russia's defeat and the end of the global crisis closer!

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**Since the beginning of the war against Ukraine in 2014, Russia has constantly been spreading aggressive propaganda.**

Russian propagandists actively share fakes about Ukrainians, falsify and appropriate Ukrainian history. Putin has repeatedly stated that the Ukrainian nation does not exist. Since February 24, 2022, propaganda has reached a new level: the Russian media directly call for a “resolution of the Ukrainian issue”, and TV presenters openly call for “killing Ukrainian children.” Propaganda is also a weapon that kills. Hate speech has always been an essential tool in wars. The aggressor needs it to justify one’s aggressive actions and keep public support. Since the Second World War, the actions of propagandists have been classified as international crimes. Incitement to genocide or crimes against humanity received the highest degrees of punishment. Two Nazi propagandists were tried at the Nuremberg Trials, one of whom was executed. Neither killed anyone, but they played a significant role in the mass killing of civilians. The Russian media lie and incite the killing of civilians, and they are a threat not only to Ukrainians. 

Any nation can become a target of propaganda. Russian propagandists must answer for spreading lies in an international court. 

Visual author: Khrystyna Valko

**Russia tries to persuade the world that it is a victim, not an aggressor.**

To do this, Russians sow countless lies such as “preemptive strike on Ukraine which planned to attack Russia” and “protection from NATO that wants to destroy Russia using Ukrainians.”  “Ukraine plans to use a “dirty bomb” of its own production” is the newest lie. To make the Western world believe in this, Shoigu, Russia’s Minister of Defense, personally called defense ministries of various countries. However, Russia has long lost the trust of the global community, given that Russia’s official statements are tales reinforced by domestic propaganda. It is not difficult to check that Russia is lying. Ukraine has invited an IAEA mission to check the condition of all facilities that, according to Russia, are involved in producing a radiological bomb. Russia uses this narrative to make the world distrust Ukraine. However, it only achieves the opposite, since you can always verify Ukrainian statements, unlike Russian ones. 

Ukraine is a civilized European state that wants to live in peace. Do not trust Russians and help Ukrainians!

Visual author: Khrysryna Valko

**Russia cannot defeat Ukrainians on the battlefield, so it terrorizes civilians.**

Russian missiles target energy infrastructure all over Ukraine. As of mid-October, they managed to bring down more than 40% of the country's energy facilities. These strikes bring destruction and death to the deep Ukrainian rear, but they do not affect the situation at the front in any way. Russians are trying to cause a humanitarian catastrophe to kill even more civilians. To spread panic among Ukrainians, they use destruction, mass casualties, electricity and heating cut-offs. After all, the looming winter is Putin's last hope in the war against Ukraine. 

To protect themselves against Russian terror, Ukrainians need air defense systems. Without them, the country faces more destruction, many victims, and a cold winter.

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**The Russian war fundamentally changed the geopolitical mood of Ukrainians.**

Ukraine’s largest river, Dnipro, divides the country into the Eastern and the Western parts. Before the war, most residents of the Eastern part, which was once colonized by the Russian empire, were more tolerant toward Russia. The Western part, on the other hand, had more pro-European views as its territories once belonged to the Austro-Hungarian Empire and the Polish Commonwealth. Ukrainian sociology reflected similar sentiments: according to the Kyiv International Institute of Sociology, in 2020 and early 2021, 41% of respondents had a good attitude toward Russia, and 42% had a bad one. After the start of the full-scale Russian war, the situation changed: according to the sociological group “Rating”, 86% of respondents support Ukraine's accession to the EU, and 83% support accession to NATO. Ukrainians do not consider themselves a formal or informal part of Russia and want to preserve their country’s independence. This shows the manipulations behind public figures talking about the possibility of “peaceful” negotiations as Russia keeps occupying Eastern and Southern regions and attempts annexing these regions. The world wants the crisis caused by the Russian war to end as soon as possible. However, surrendering parts of Ukrainian territories to Russia will stimulate the aggressor to continue the war. For Russia, “peaceful” plans are a manifestation of weakness, which will eventually encourage Russians to start new conflicts. 
Russia must lose the same way the German Third Reich lost. This is the only thing that will stop the war and the crisis. Do not believe Russia's provocative statements and support Ukraine!

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**Ukrainian utility workers during the war are among the most efficient in the world.**

Despite the daily Russian shelling, houses in Ukraine-controlled territories are connected to electricity, gas, water, and communication grids. Ukrainian utility services work quickly and efficiently. They often do their work under Russian bombardment. Russian rockets regularly kill people who repair water pipes and electricity networks or clear the rubble of destroyed buildings. Utility workers belong to the heroes of the Ukrainian invisible front. Their work gives Ukrainians peace even in the direst situations. 

The next winter in Ukraine will probably be the most difficult in the last thirty years. But Ukraine will persevere and win the war because all Ukrainians are making maximum efforts for this. Support Ukrainians to bring this victory moment closer. 

Visual author: Khrysryna Valko

**The harder Russians shell Ukrainian cities, the more Ukrainians donate to the army.**

In nine months of the war, people started responding to fear with rational rage that motivates Ukrainians to act. Ukraine’s Armed Forces destroy the enemy even more tenaciously, volunteers cover the needs of their wards even more actively, and Ukrainians donate more money. After the mass bombing of Ukrainian cities in early October 2022, Ukrainians collected more than 350 million hryvnias (~ $9.6 million) to purchase [kamikaze drones for Ukraine’s Armed Forces.](https://prytulafoundation.org/uk/home/support_page) The willingness to donate money to charity does not mean that the income of Ukrainians stayed the same. The Ukrainian economy fell by more than 30%. However, more Ukrainians are ready to dedicate at least a small amount of money to draw the victory over Russia closer. 

Join the benefactors! Everyone can contribute so that world peace comes sooner.

Visual author: Sviatoslav Zembitskyy

**Russia once again simulated democracy by holding "referendums" in the occupied territories of Ukraine.**

The aggressor country turned the instrument of voluntary expression of people’s will into a forced voting procedure. Russian soldiers went to people's homes together with representatives of election commissions and demanded people to vote. When the total number of votes in the "referendum" still turned out to be insufficient, the Russian Federation even counted the incomplete ballots as in favor of annexation. The Russians are trying to create an impression that their country protects the interests of the Ukrainian people. In fact, Russia – like many parasites – needs this imitation to survive. This is because Russia still hopes that it will be able to win the war against Ukraine and return to the community of civilized countries with time. That is why the occupiers create illegitimate documents and want both the West and Russians to believe in their authenticity. Remember that the Russian Federation violates the laws, destroys the security system of the world, threatens with nuclear strikes, and is preparing for further escalation of hostilities in Europe.

Do not trust Russia, condemn its actions and demand your governments to completely isolate Russia from the world.

**Why does Russia want to seize Ukraine? Putin's initial plan to gain complete control over Ukrainians in three days failed.**

The large-scale war has been going on for more than seven months. The losses of the Russian Federation are more than 55,000 dead soldiers. The resources of the Russian army are running out, so Putin announced the urgent mobilization of 300,000 Russians. He wants to win the war in Ukraine to maintain his power. Therefore, he now calls on Russians not just to fight against the "Ukrainian Nazis" but to defend themselves against the collective West. The Russian dictator believes that the West wants to "dismantle Russia." For the most part, Russians support Putin, although he is ready to keep destroying not only Ukrainians but also Russians, the Russian economy, and the future of his country. The Russian Federation wants to become a "superpower" and strengthen its influence on the countries of the former Soviet Union. The ideals of modern Russia include terror, murders, an arms race, and human rights violations. The aggressor country must be stopped now. 

The change in Putin's rhetoric means a threat not only to Ukraine's future existence but also to the development of the entire Western civilization.

Visual author: Iryna Zarubina

**Europe is once again paying the price for freedom and democracy, but it does so with money.**

Europe introduced sanctions that should weaken Russia. Europe gives loans to Ukraine to support its economy during the war. Europe is facing a response from Russia, which is using gas as a weapon. Russia is trying to break the unity within the EU by manipulating energy prices. This comes on top of the highest inflation in the last 40 years, which comes as a result of printing money during the pandemic. Does it feel good to pay this price? No. But if Europe does not pay this price with money, this will pose a threat to the basic values and the usual way of life, to which generations of Europeans have already become accustomed. Ukrainians, too, did not want to believe in the war before the start of the full-scale invasion, and they were more worried about the fall in GDP. Now, however, they are forced to think how to survive. Before the start of the Russian war in Ukraine, the EU was too dependent on Russian energy sources. European politicians saw Russia as their firewood shed, from which you can get energy: oil and gas, and where you just need to send money. The economic model of many states became reliable on these cheap energy sources.  Billions of dollars went to Russia, fueling Putin's thirst for conquests and revenge. Unfortunately, many Europeans have forgotten the golden rule of diversification which means that you should not put all your eggs in one basket. Europeans made their market too dependent on one gas supplier: Russia. Of course, when the war began, Russia exploited this weakness because it knew about it. The EU believed that this weapon could not be used against Europe because it did not benefit Putin. Indeed, Putin is much more dependent on the European market than Europe is on Russian energy, but he still took this step. The Russian budget has already become deficit due to Putin's self-embargo, so Gazprom is reducing production and will never again become that rich company that buys football clubs and some European politicians. The EU needs time to correct the mistakes of the past because now, it needs to build infrastructure to get gas from other regions of the world. Until then, it is necessary to reduce consumption and pay more due to the shortage in the market. This is the price for freedom, which, fortunately, can be paid with money. Otherwise, we would have to pay for this freedom with the lives of Europeans. Ukraine is currently paying this price for everyone. 

_Serhiy Fursa, investment banker, deputy director at Dragon Capital_

Visual author: Anastasiia Hlivinska

**In Ukraine, the Russians are repeating the scenarios of the Hitler regime of the 1930s and 1940s.**

Even the beginning of the full-scale invasion is an allusion to the World War II: the Russians invaded Ukraine at about 4 a.m. without declaring war. Before the start of mass hostilities, the Russian Federation declared its protection of Russian-speakers in Eastern Ukraine and supported separatists in Donbas in 2014. In the same way, Hitler "protected" German speakers in the Sudetenland in 1938. The Russians annexed Crimea in March 2014, just as the Germans conducted the Anschluss of Austria in March 1938. Russians consider themselves a superior nation and are punishing their “little brothers” as they call Ukrainians for every manifestation of independence. This can be seen from the intensity of the bombings of Ukrainian cities, which take place on significant dates for Ukraine. For example, on June 28, on the Day of the Constitution of Ukraine, the Russians massively shelled the South and East of Ukraine, and the day before, they destroyed a shopping center in the city of Kremenchuk. On July 28, on Ukraine's Statehood Day, Russia massively shelled 7 regions of the country. Russians are a nation that wants to start a new world war according to Hitler's methods and take over Europe. 

Ukraine needs weapons to stop the aggressor and end this war!

Visual author: Nastya Gorban

**Russians are bombing power plants, water supply systems, and other infrastructure in Ukraine to force Ukrainians to surrender.**

The Russian Federation is losing battles in the east of Ukraine and is barely holding on to the captured southern regions. That is why more and more often Russian missiles cut cities off the grid, damage water supply systems, and hit objects near Zaporizhzhya and Pivdenno-Ukrayinsk nuclear power plants. Russia increases the pressure on Ukraine this way. The occupiers want the Ukrainian authorities to take a seat at the negotiation table and give up on recapturing the Russia-occupied territories. If successful, the Russian Federation will have time to restore its military power and economy and gain a formal reason to demand the lifting Western sanctions. Ukrainians are holding on and refusing to negotiate with the aggressor country. Russia must lose the war in Ukraine and answer for its crimes. Otherwise, the Russian war will spread to other European countries. 

Do not forget that Ukraine is fighting the Russian invasion of the EU’s border!

**Why not only Putin but every Russian is to blame for the war against Ukraine?**

1\. "This is Putin's war, not the Russian war." Putin started this war and ordered the destruction of Ukrainian cities. But these are Russian citizens, who drop bombs on residential buildings, kill civilians during evacuations, torture Ukrainian prisoners and locals, loot and destroy property. Similarly, Putin did not perpetrate the genocide of Ukrainians in Bucha and Mariupol. Russian soldiers did, although Putin is undoubtedly guilty of it, too, as the head of a terrorist state.

2\. "The war is just Putin's sick ambitions." Long before Putin was born, different Russian regimes and rulers spent centuries trying to seize Ukrainian territories, destroy the culture and the language, and deny the existence of Ukrainians as a separate nation. A recent CNN survey shows that 64% of Russian responders consider Ukrainians and Russians as one nation.

3\. "I did not kill anyone." Everyone who lives or works in Russia sponsors the war. The money from the Russian budget buys missiles and bombs flying at Ukrainian cities. To be complicit in the war, you don't need to kill anyone as long as you buy ammunition.

4\. "We can't change anything." Change is never easy. Over the last 30 years, three revolutions have taken place in Ukraine. Ukrainians went out on mass protests, disagreeing with the policies of the governments of that time. Ukrainians paid a terrible price in 2014; back then, more than a hundred protesters were killed. On the contrary, Russians keep believing the propaganda unconditionally and are afraid or unwilling to change anything.

5\. "Why are Russian athletes, scientists, or artists at fault?" Abroad they all represent Russia, the aggressor state that invaded the territory of independent Ukraine and is killing people there.

Demand that Russians bear responsibility for the war against Ukraine. Remind them that not only Putin is to blame, but every one of them. 

Visual author: Khrystyna Valko

**The Russian war in Ukraine damages the environment in Europe.**

Using ammunition and military equipment significantly increases CO2 emissions, accelerates global climate change, and exacerbates the greenhouse effect. 
For example, during the eight years of the war in Iraq, carbon dioxide emissions could amount to 600 million tons, equal to the annual CO2 emissions of France and Spain combined. The scale of emissions of the Russian war in Ukraine is likely to have exceeded these indicators. 
Poisonous substances produced by explosions enter groundwater and reservoirs affecting seas and rivers in Europe. This summer, European countries suffered from a severe drought, and many rivers have dried up at their banks and thinned out. The water resources issue is crucial, and the Russian war worsens the situation. The Russians, led by Putin, seek to satisfy their imperial ambitions and do not care about the price the world pays for it. Citizens of every country must protect their lives and the lives of future generations. Russia must face punishment for crimes against humanity. 

Support increasing pressure on Russia to force Russian soldiers out of Ukraine and prevent them from starting wars in the future. 

Visual author: Iryna Zarubina

**Russia's attack on Ukraine exposed a crisis in humanitarian law.** 

In particular, accusations are flying against the International Committee of the Red Cross for its inability to fulfill its obligations. On May 16, during the evacuation of Ukrainian defenders from "Azovstal" in Mariupol, the Red Cross acted as a neutral mediator when the soldiers were exiting the city, which did not spare the Ukrainian prisoners of war. In late July, Russian artillery fired at a prison in a temporarily occupied Olenivka, where they kept Ukrainian prisoners of war. Approximately 40 people were killed, and another 130 were injured. The Red Cross representatives failed to access the prisoners of war. Neither were they able to reach the wounded Ukrainian soldiers and the bodies of those killed in Olenivka. In early August, the human rights organization Amnesty International noted in its report that the Ukrainian military endangered civilians by stationing in schools and hospitals. This statement is a cynical manipulation. At the same time, Amnesty International did not pay enough attention to the crimes committed by Russians in Ukraine. Such statements are part of Russia's discrediting campaign against Ukraine. 

Russian aggression in Ukraine has shown that the conventional approaches of international human rights organizations are ineffective. Instead, such institutions should unite and build new rules for dealing with Russia.

Visual author: Khrystyna Valko

**Athletic victories at international competitions lift the national spirit.**

Contrary to popular belief, sports have never been and never will be outside of politics. During the Russian-Ukrainian war, Ukrainians show even greater support for their athletes than before. The Ukrainian flag waving in front of hundreds of cameras reminds the world of the country fighting for its freedom today. The match between Ukrainian boxer Oleksandr Usyk and British Anthony Joshua is one of the significant recent sports victories. 
On August 20, Usyk defended the world champion title in the most prestigious weight category, showing that Ukrainians are unbreakable not only on the battlefield but also in sports. Besides, Usyk reminded the world about Russia's war against Ukraine on live TV. At the press conference before the fight, the Ukrainian boxer wore Ukrainian national clothes and sang a popular Ukrainian song, "Hey, Hey, Rise Up!" Immediately after the match, Usyk ended his speech with the words, "Ukraine will win!" 

Ukraine will win, but it will happen faster with support from the rest of the world. Support Ukrainians, so the only fields they'll have to win at would be sports fields.

Visual author: Nastya Gorban

**The EU must resist Russian interference in the public dialogue of the EU member states.** 

Russia manipulates democratic processes in Europe using propaganda and pro-Russian activists. The recent protest of thousands of people in the capital of the Czech Republic, Prague, clearly shows that. The protesters demanded the government's re-election and restored cooperation with the Russian Federation, especially concerning purchasing Russian gas and oil. The aggressor country is amping up its pressure on the European community in all possible ways so that the West relieves the sanctions introduced due to the Russian war in Ukraine. It is crucial to understand that Europe will be able to reject Russian energy within a year. Consequently, Russia will lose one of its last leverages against Western countries. So Russia is using all its resources to force the EU to negotiate. 

However, negotiations with the aggressor are possible only after the Russian withdrawal of troops from Ukraine and admission of guilt in starting the war. Other scenarios will only increase Russia's appetite for further invasion of European countries. 

Visual author: Iryna Zarubina

**Any response from the Ukrainian military to the invading country is justified.** 

After the plan to seize Ukraine quickly failed, Russia launched a new stage of this war: an informational one. The Russian Federation is trying to force the world to change its view of the Russian war and reduce the support for Ukraine from the international community. International organizations criticize the actions of Ukrainian defenders instead of helping the Armed Forces fight against the aggressor, and thus, they become complicit in the Russian information war. **How did the name of Ukrainian bread help identify saboteurs?** At the beginning of the full-scale Russian war, Ukrainians asked suspicious persons to say "palianytsia". Russians cannot pronounce this word correctly because this combination of sounds is atypical for them, but Russian-speaking Ukrainians can do it. Palianytsia is a type of ancient Ukrainian bread, most often cooked for holidays and used in traditional ceremonies.

During the war, "palianytsia" generated many jokes and memes. This word became a somewhat humorous but practical linguistic password, thanks to which Ukrainians defined themselves in Ukraine and worldwide.

This practice of identifying enemies by pronunciation is not new. During the Second World War, the Dutch used the name of the city Scheveningen to identify Germans who mispronounced it. The Danish watchword against German soldiers was "rodgrod med flode". The British tested the Nazis with the word "squirrel." Russian propagandists once discussed "palianytsia" in one of their TV programs, claiming that this word is a piece of cake for them.

But even there, they were making mistakes. Instead of saying palianytsia, they kept saying "polunytsia," which means strawberry in Ukrainian. The Russian propagandists were sure that the linguistic password was the word for a summer berry

**Here's a selection of popular phrases that reflect Ukrainian war experiences.**

**Borsch is a 500-years-old culinary tradition of Ukrainians.** The first written mention of borsch dates back to 1584.  But it is obvious that in modern Ukraine borsch, an important first course, has a much longer tradition.

Today borsch is made with beets, cabbage, potatoes, carrots, onions, and tomatoes (or tomato paste).  However, there is no single recipe because each family cooks this meal in its own way.  Ingredients vary depending on the development of food culture in a particular region of Ukraine and the historical period, but the sweet and sour fragrant taste remains a must. Borsch is also among the ritual dishes.  It is cooked for a memorial service.  In the Ukrainian diasporas of Canada, Brazil, and the United States, it is a wedding dish, too.

Ukraine has applied to include the Ukrainian borsch in the UNESCO World Intangible Heritage List.  When Ukraine wins, Ukrainians will cook a lot of borsch and invite everyone, who helped fight Russia, to try it.  The main thing now is to continue supplying Ukraine with weapons and providing economic assistance.

**Russia must pay for Ukraine's reconstruction.**

 In three months of full-scale war, Russia inflicted more than $105 billion in damages on Ukrainian infrastructure. Russian occupiers destroyed or seized more than 200 businesses, 500 medical facilities, 295 bridges, and 12 civilian airports. They also destroyed tens of thousands of apartment buildings. The war goes on, but Ukrainians are already preparing to rebuild their country. Ukraine is currently working on a phased recovery plan, similar to the concept of the Marshall Plan for post-World War II Europe. The government plans to allocate 1.5 billion hryvnias from the Ukrainian state budget for the first stage. Ukraine will also turn to partner countries for financial assistance. All efforts must be dedicated to defeating Russia and forcing the Kremlin to admit its guilt. Russia must pay reparations for destroyed Ukraine and compensate for the world's economic losses.

**In the war with Russia, Ukrainians only need the victory.** **A peace agreement with Russia is not yet possible.**

Today, Russians are committing genocide on the territory of Ukraine and destroying entire cities, occupying regions, forcibly deporting people to Russia, and ruining the Ukrainian economy. Such atrocities come as a consequence of Russia never facing punishment for its previous military campaigns. Over the past few decades, Russians have committed war crimes in Venezuela, Syria, Georgia, and African countries. Unless Russia suffers a crushing defeat, it will not stop its aggression. Only Ukraine's victory will allow it to sign a peace agreement with Russia. The peace agreement is only the first step toward creating conditions for secure coexistence with Russia. 

Support Ukraine, so war criminals face justice and peace reigns sooner in Europe.

Every day, Russia spends $900 million on the war in Ukraine. These funds go toward maintaining Russian soldiers, providing them with ammunition, and repairing equipment. Such daily expenditures are comparable, for example, to the annual GDP of the small island nation of Saint Kitts and Nevis. Russia funds its war in Ukraine with gas and oil sales. In the meantime, 30% of Russia's territory still doesn't have a centralized gas supply. The Russian Federation plans to finish connecting citizens to the gas grid only in 2030.
Interestingly, in 2022 Russia plans to spend only $1.5 billion on gas networks. Instead of improving the quality of life for its citizens, modern Russian funds wars. As long as Russia makes enormous profits from its energy monopoly in Europe and Asia, the threat of new wars remains high. The world must refuse Russian oil and gas as soon as possible because it keeps financing wars!

**In the two months of the war, the Russians committed more than 250 war crimes against Ukraine's cultural heritage.**

More than 100 objects of culture, architecture, and religion were damaged or destroyed. You can find detailed information on the map of cultural losses. 
Russia targeted the Mariupol Drama Theater, destroyed a century-old Belgian lyceum in the Luhansk region, and a 160-year-old church in northern Ukraine. The 500-year-old Svyatohirsk Monastery in eastern Ukraine was partially destroyed. The museum of Hryhoriy Skovoroda, a Ukrainian philosopher, in the Kharkiv region was bombed. Missiles also targeted the island of Khortytsia in Zaporizhya, southern Ukraine: a place of the glory of the Ukrainian Cossacks.

 Russia has waged war to wipe out the Ukrainian nation and culture. Russians try to create a new empire on the bones of people living next to Russia. Help Ukrainians stop this wild invasion! Help protect our shared cultural heritage!

**Ukrainian women have always defended their state on an equal footing with men.** 

For example, Olena Stepaniv became one of the first women officers in the world. In the early 20th century, she fought for Ukraine's independence in the ranks of the Ukrainian Sich Riflemen. Today women comprise more than 20% of Ukraine's Armed Forces. This figure is one of the highest among NATO countries. Women in the Ukrainian army have equal rights with men, which is fixed in the 2018 law. Many Ukrainian women are ranking officers. Recently, the first woman became the head of an artillery unit of Ukraine's Armed Forces. Her name is Lyubov Plaksyuk, and she used to work as a history teacher. Ukrainian women die heroically for the freedom of their country. In March, Sergeant Inna Derusova was posthumously awarded the Hero of Ukraine and the Order of the Golden Star, the highest military honors in the country.

Ukraine needs large-scale supplies of modern weapons from partner countries! This way, we will be able to resist the aggressor more effectively.

**Russia consistently promotes the ludicrous narrative that the Ukrainian language derives from Russian.** In the early 1930s, the vocabulary of the Ukrainian language was forcefully made more similar to Russian. Many Ukrainian words in academic dictionaries were replaced with their Russian equivalents. In fact, the Bolsheviks kept implementing the guidelines from the Valuev Circular of 1863 and the Ems decree of 1867, which prohibited the printing of books in Ukrainian. The Russian Empire and later the Soviet Union sought to turn Ukraine into a Russian colony. Russian propagandists still exploit the myth of the Soviet Union creating Ukraine. Russia can not forgive Ukrainians who still preserved their culture and history after centuries of repression and want to build their state. Ukraine is not and never was a part of Russia of its own will. Help defend the independence of Ukraine: increase pressure on Russia!

Russians force Ukrainians through filtration camps. Russian secret services employees illegally interrogate civilians who try to leave the occupied territories or the war zone. Often, the invaders forcefully deport civilians to Russia after the "filtration." This way Russians try to find those fictitious "Nazis" among Ukrainians. Most times the "filtration" takes place in poorly equipped trailers in the middle of the fields. So, Ukrainians spend days or even weeks waiting for illegal inspections in these inhumane conditions. More than a million Ukrainians have already gone through this process, including about 200 thousand children. The fate of those who did not pass "filtration" is unknown. Filtration camps are a war crime, and Russia must be punished. Help us bring this punishment faster: support Ukraine!

So what does Ukraine want?  Today, Ukrainians are fighting for their independence, which Russia has been trying to destroy for hundreds of years. Since the days of the Russian Empire and then the Soviet Union, Russians have been doing all they can to keep Ukraine on Moscow's short leash. Russia stays convinced that the Soviet Union still exists, so Ukraine, as its former republic, must obey the will of the Kremlin. Russia has hindered the Ukrainian efforts for European integration, funding pro-Russian media in Ukraine, paying experts to broadcast Kremlin narratives, and sponsoring pro-Russian political parties. Ukraine continued its path toward the EU and NATO membership. Therefore, on February 24, Russia tried to seize power in Ukraine by force. Ukraine is not part of Russia. It has a unique language, culture, and history. So Ukraine wants to decide its future!

Why do Ukrainians sing "Hey Hey Rise Up" again, now with the whole world?
 In the first days of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the leader of the Ukrainian band Boombox, Andriy Khlyvnyuk, who is currently serving in the Territorial Defense Forces, sang this song a cappella on Sofia Square in Kyiv.  At the same time, the popular author of electronic music from South Africa, The Kiffness, made a remix of Andriy's performance.  Recently, for the first time in 30 years, Pink Floyd co-recorded the single "Hey Hey Rise Up" with Andriy Khlyvnyuk, and the song immediately topped the iTunes charts worldwide.  More than 100 years ago, the Sich Riflemen, a Ukrainian volunteer legion in the Austro-Hungarian army, adopted the song as their anthem.  In World War I, the volunteers fought against the Russian Empire army.
 Ukraine is fighting Russia again.  Support Ukrainians - let's sing together!

Russians like to write "messages" on missiles they use against peaceful Ukrainian cities. When the Ukrainian band Kalush Orchestra called on the Eurovision stage to rescue the military blocked at Azovstal in Mariupol, the next day the Russians wrote on their missiles "Kalush, as you asked! #to Azovstal". When Russians launched missiles to fire on the Kramatorsk railway station on April 8, 2022, they wrote "For children" on them. That cynical attack killed 61 people, including 7 children. The tradition of making inscriptions on shells and missiles dates back to the First World War. During World War II, Soviet troops also wrote similar messages to their enemies. At the time, it helped soldiers maintain morale while defending their land. Today, the Russian military's inscriptions left on the missiles are a cynical and cruel gesture by the aggressor army. These missiles kill civilians and destroy peaceful cities in Ukraine only because they do not like Ukraine's political course. Russia must be stopped so that such "messages" won't land in any other country!

The Russian war is destroying Ukrainian nature. During the first two months of the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the Russians committed more than 200 acts of ecocide here. They fired on chemical and nuclear power plants, set oil depots on fire, and detonated thousands of shells. The worst situation is in Mariupol. Tens of thousands of murdered civilians have been chaotically buried or are decomposing in the open air. Sewage is not being cleaned. Garbage is not taken out. All infrastructure is destroyed. Corpse poison and human waste seep into groundwater and the Sea of Azov. There is a high chance that chemical compounds from the steel factory Azovstal could get into the sea in case of a large-scale shelling. Other countries also experience the consequences of the barbaric disturbance of ecosystems in Ukraine. The only chance to save the environment is to force Russia to stop this war! We need more sanctions and a complete embargo on trade with Russia.

Russia cannot do without goods produced in the West. Despite claims of alleged successful import substitution, the Russian Ministry of Industry and Trade has allowed so-called parallel imports. This means that Russia will import and resell high-tech goods from dozens of foreign brands without their consent. These include medical, sound, and photo equipment, XBox sets, Apple watches, Bentley, Tesla, and Mercedes-Benz cars, and so on. 
Russia is not able to create its own model of the modern world economy despite its claims. At one time, Iran tried to implement a similar scenario, but the country has been under Western sanctions for more than 40 years and has so far failed to introduce successful import substitution.
Russia still has funds to purchase goods and services abroad. This allows them to postpone the negative effects of sanctions on Russians. That is also why they still believe in Putin's ability to provide them with a decent life so people in Russia keep on supporting the war against Ukraine.
We need a full energy embargo and a ban on trade with Russia! This can make Russians realize faster that the Kremlin's policies are leading to their impoverishment and isolation.

Russia is going to hold a “referendum” in Kherson, a Southern Ukrainian city under temporary Russian occupation. Through this so-called referendum, Russians want to show that the people of Kherson allegedly wish to create a pseudo “Kherson People’s Republic.” Meanwhile, Kherson residents with Ukrainian flags keep going to rallies to preserve Ukraine's sovereignty. They are being shot at, abducted, tortured, and intimidated by the Russian military which tries to stop their resistance.
Russia is actively using pseudo-referendum technic as well as the formation of pseudo-republics to legalize its own military aggression. This is exactly how Russia acted in 2014 during the capture of Crimea. According to this scenario, fake “republics” were also created in eastern Ukraine: the so-called “Donetsk People's Republic” and “Luhansk People's Republic”. Prior to that, Russia did the same in Georgia with South Ossetia and Abkhazia and in Moldova with Transnistria. The world is projected not to recognize these “referendums”.
Moscow has been using these technologies for over a hundred years. In 1917, the Russian Bolshevik army captured Kharkiv and proclaimed a pseudo-republic there. The USSR was formed using such methods. 
Ukraine needs more support to prevent Russia's creation of new pseudo-republics!

Russian Church is a massive propaganda mouthpiece.  It is completely under the patronage of Moscow and is part of the state apparatus.  In their sermons, Russian priests preach about  the "holy war against Ukraine" and bless Russian military to murder Ukrainians.  It is easy to explain this zealotry with which the Russian Church is serving the Kremlin.  In 1920-30s, Stalin liquidated the first ROC (Russian Orthodox Church), and then, during the Second World War, he restored it.  With religion, it was easier to control the population. To achieve that, Orthodox priests became employees of the Soviet security services. Russian priests spread Kremlin's propaganda all over Eastern Europe for decades.  Before February 24, 2022, the Russian Orthodox Church had a considerable influence in Ukraine.  After Russia's full-scale invasion in Ukraine, the priests of the Russian Orthodox Church were repeatedly detained for collaboration and for transferring information to the enemy.  Now, Ukraine experiences a wave of public rejection of the Russian Church by religious communities.  Russian Church is not about Christian values, but about exaltation of imperial ideology.  Do not trust it!

Russia denies people the right to live on their native land.  So it was in 1944, when the Kremlin falsely accused Crimean Tatars of collaborating with the Nazis.  Then, on 18-21 of May,  nearly 194,000 Crimean Tatars, the indigenous people of Crimea, were deported against their will.  Nearly half of deportees died on the road and in the first years of exile. Crimean Tatars could return to the peninsula only in 1990s, and since then, they have struggled for years to regain their rights.
 After the annexation of Crimea in 2014, Russia again launched massive repression of the Crimean Tatars.  This time, the Kremlin wrongly accused Crimean Tatars of terrorism and conducted searches, detained, and imprisoned people for up to 20 years in a penal colony. Some Crimean Tatars may face life imprisonment.  There are cases of killings and disappearances in the peninsula, too.  This way, Russia is punishing people for disloyalty to the occupation authorities.  Crimean Tatars are again forcibly deported to Russia, where they are being judged.  After 70 years, indigenous people of Crimea are once again denied their homeland. 
Nowadays, Russia extends criminal practice of deportation to other occupied territories of Ukraine.  This must stop!  Lobby your politicians to give Ukrainian army arms and strengthen sanctions against Russia!

Russia has always used language as an instrument of aggression. As early as the 18th century, the Russian Empire banned scientific activities and book printing in the Ukrainian language, and closed Ukrainian-language schools and cultural centers. During the last three centuries, the Ukrainian language has been banned 134 times. As a result, almost a third of Ukrainians today speak Russian. Russia is actively spreading the myth of oppression of the Russian-speaking population in Ukraine. This was one of the reasons for Russia to start the war in eastern Ukraine, capture Crimea, and later, launch a full-scale invasion. Now the State Duma of the Russian Federation is considering an absurd bill to recognize all those who “speak Russian” as “compatriots.” This should give Russia the right to “protect” Russian-speaking people around the world from far-fetched oppression. So, if there are Russian-speaking communities in your country, there is a chance that Russia may come to “liberate” them.

"Russia's war inspired many Ukrainian artists to write new songs about Ukraine's fight. If you liked the song “Stefania” by the rap band Kalush Orchestra from Eurovision 2022, we offer you a selection of contemporary Ukrainian music about the struggle, faith, and victory:
1\. “Misto Mariyi” by Океан Ельзи (“City of Mary”, dedicated to Mariupol).
2\. “Dobroho vechora, my z Ukrayiny” by PROBASS ∆ HARDI (“Good evening, we are from Ukraine!”: This is how Ukrainians greet each other now).
3\. “Zaryadjay” by Фіолет (“Charge”: a song of gratitude to Ukraine’s defenders).
4\. “Bude vesna” by Макс Барських (“There will be spring”: with faith in the future victory).
5\. “Yak ty?” by THE HARDKISS (“How are you?”: These words are most often written by Ukrainians to their relatives).
6\. “Ridni moyi” by alyona alyona feat. Jerry Heil (“My family”: Ukrainian families are separated by the war, and this hurts).
7\. “Heroyam” (UA) by БЕЗ ОБМЕЖЕНЬ (“To heroes” - Glory to Ukraine!).
8\. “Kalyna” by Go\_A (Kalyna, or red viburnum, is a symbol of Ukraine, believed to protect against evil).
9\. “My vas vsikh ubyem!” by SURFACE TENSION (“We will kill you all!”: contains explicit language, but also shows how fierce the fight is).
10\. “Arta” by Пирятин (contains explicit language; however, this song is very inspiring to Ukrainian soldiers).
Listen to Ukrainian songs and support Ukraine!"

On May 9, Russia pompously celebrates Victory Day in World War II. In terms of scale, it is the largest Russian holiday of the year. While Europe commemorates this greatest tragedy of the 20th century, the Russians are holding a large-scale military parade and salutes. World War II ended 77 years ago. However, the farther we move from this date, the louder and more absurd the celebration in Moscow gets. Every year, huge posters of Stalin are carried at the parades on Red Square, and pseudo-veterans, children in soldiers’ uniforms, and infants in trolleys decorated as tanks are taking part in the celebration. All this indicates that for almost 80 years, Russia didn’t experience anything that would make people as proud as May 9. The Russians are aggressively using the cult of victory over Nazism to militarize society and incite hostility to the Western world. Today, Russians refer to Ukrainians as Nazis. If the war in Ukraine is not stopped, tomorrow they will fight the "Nazis" all over Europe.

Over the past hundred years, Russia has conducted 31 military campaigns. Its longest period of peace lasted 12 years: between the attack on Hungary in 1956 and the attack on Czechoslovakia in 1968. Russia borders 14 countries. It attacked 10 of them. Most of the modern territory of Russia was once occupied by nomadic tribes, which significantly influenced the formation of the cultural basis of the Russians. The cult of aggression and raids has been successful throughout Russia's history: in the Russian Empire, the Soviet Union, and then 20 years of the Putin regime. These cultural features have shaped state institutions that cultivate a policy of hatred and imperialism. Most Russians approve of wars of aggression because they believe that their country is the greatest and has the right to attack other states. The Russians have not yet fully felt the effects of economic sanctions. Their standard of living has not deteriorated enough to provoke mass protests inside Russia. Therefore, demand tougher sanctions to encourage Russians to change their country from within!

The Russians are robbing Ukrainian farmers and illegally exporting grain, fuel, agricultural machinery, and the first seasonal crops from Ukraine. Such cases were recorded in four regions of Ukraine, which are under temporary occupation by Russia. This is a conscious Russian policy: for example, the local authorities of the Krasnoyarsk region in Russia have decided to "expropriate the surplus of last year's and this year's harvest" from the South of Ukraine. The occupying power takes away the sowing material from the farmers, but at the same time requires them to successfully sow and then send new crops to Russia. Russians prohibit the farmers to pay taxes to the state budget of Ukraine. In case of disagreement, the soldiers threaten the locals with physical violence. Russia is repeating Soviet policy of mass looting of Ukrainian peasants in the late 1920s. This is how Soviets started the Holodomor, a genocide of Ukrainians via mass starvation, in 1932-33. This is also how Soviets destroyed the private property on Ukrainian lands. Under the guise of a “war of liberation against the Nazis,” Russia is provoking famine in the occupied territories and destroying Ukraine as a competitor in the international food market. Do not buy Russian goods! Demand your country to renounce any cooperation with Russia!

Russian soldiers take children hostage in Ukraine’s temporarily occupied territories. Russian soldiers also force children’s mothers to spy on Ukrainian servicemen and find out their locations. If mothers refuse, Russians threaten to kill their children. People are forced to make a tough choice: either to lose their children or to become traitors to the Motherland and be punished for it. The Commissioner for Human Rights in Ukraine Lyudmila Denisova has repeatedly reported on the mass abduction of orphans by the aggressor state. The orphans are deported to Russia and given to Russian families. Putin even initiated amendments to the adoption law in order “to organize an accelerated procedure for the adoption of children from Donbas”. Call on your authorities and the international community to prevent the abduction of Ukrainian children!

Some European organizations are urging their governments not to send arms to Ukraine. They claim that without weapons, there will be no war. What’s wrong with this view?
Without modern arms, Ukraine will not be able to stop Russia. So then, Russia with its imperial ambitions can go further. It is already threatening Poland, Romania, Finland, and the Baltic countries. In the 1940s, Winston Churchill asked the United States for military assistance. If American pacifists had persuaded Roosevelt not to supply arms to Europeans back then, there would be no free and democratic Europe today.
For Ukrainians, the calls not to provide arms sound like this: surrender or die. If Ukraine does not maintain its defense, are you ready to be the next to die from Russian shells?

Russians are selling merchandize in support of the genocide of Ukrainians in Bucha. T-shirts with a text “Bucha Massacre: we can do it again” and the image of a butcher killing a pig gain positive and enthusiastic reviews from Russians. The themed merch even includes T-shirts for children. Russians are proud of the genocide of Ukrainians which they committed on the outskirts of Kyiv. With this merchandize, Russians once again remind the world that they are ready for the next acts of violence.
In general, the phrase “We can do it again” is used by Russians in the context of World War II: “Once we got to Berlin, and we can do it again.” Atrocities of the Red Army against Germans are still remembered. The path of Russia’s hero is built on blood. The only language Russians understand is the language of violence.
Putin's army is threatening with atrocities not only Ukraine but the entire world. Call on the authorities to stop Russia so you won’t have to see the merch with the name of your city and a phrase “We can do it again.”

Russia is spreading a fake that it's fighting against the Nazis in Ukraine. In particular, they direct their Nazi accusations against the Azov Special Operations Detachment which is defending Mariupol. Who are the fighters of Azov, and what are they fighting for?
In 2014, volunteer battalions started forming in Ukraine to help Ukrainian army fight against Russian aggression in the Donbas region. One of them was Azov, created under the auspices of the Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine. The fighters heroically defended Mariupol and its suburbs in 2014 and 2015. Subsequently, the battalion was expanded to a regiment based in Mariupol.
The Azov chevron depicts two Latin letters, I and N, which are deciphered as "the idea of ​​the nation." The tasks of the regiment are to protect the state borders of Ukraine and defend Ukrainian interests in the political and military arena. The military of any country under attack defends the very same things. Russia created a fake about Nazism within Azov to discredit the Ukrainian military defending Ukraine.

Ukrainian cities occupied by Russian troops are experiencing a humanitarian catastrophe. According to the UN, 12 million Ukrainians already need humanitarian aid. People hunt pigeons, drink water from pipes and batteries, and bury the dead in yards and playgrounds.
Ukrainian authorities hold daily talks with the occupiers on humanitarian corridors. But the Russians regularly violate agreements: they fire on humanitarian vehicles and ban the evacuation of civilians. Russia is deliberately terrorizing the Ukrainian population and causing humanitarian catastrophes.
How can you help? Contact your politicians. The authorities of each country must demand from the Russian leadership to ensure the full operation of humanitarian corridors!

The Russian army is looting Ukraine. Russian soldiers steal everything from office equipment, jewelry, money, to linen, pots, and even hairpins. They send those looted "trophies" (which weight around 50-250 kg, or 100- 500 pounds) via Belarusian mail to Russia.
The Hague and Geneva Conventions classify looting as a war crime. However, for Russia, it is a military tradition approved both by society and the government. The Russians looted during two Russian-Chechen wars, the Russian invasion of Georgia in 2008, and the war in Syria.
During the Second World War, the USSR even had a Main Trophy Department, which kept records of looting in European countries. In 1995, looting was decriminalized in Russia.
Looting is a war crime, not a tradition. The guilty must be punished!

Right before the Catholic Easter, a traditional procession will be held in Rome, presided over by Pope Francis. This year, a Ukrainian and a Russian woman who have lived in Italy for a long time will carry the Cross at the Colosseum. According to the Vatican, this should become a symbolic "reconciliation of two nations", because, as the Pope said earlier, "we are all guilty in this war."
Why is this a bad idea? Because such "reconciliation" blurs a clear division: this is the aggressor, and that is the one who suffers from aggression. This decision also transforms Russia's brutal war against Ukraine to the so-called "conflict of two neighboring nations” and blurs Russia's responsibility for the crimes committed. This procession is seen as disrespect to the Ukrainian people and the Ukrainian army, which today are desperately opposed to the invader. Those guilty of crimes against humanity must be punished.
Do not support such "actions of reconciliation", do not give the aggressor a chance to avoid responsibility!

The Russian army is committing many crimes against civilians in Ukraine. Among the most brutal are the mass rapes of women and, unbelievably, children. The scale ofwar crimes in this category is difficult to measure. Victims often do not talk about what they went through. But even now, it is clear from the testimonies of Ukrainian psychologists who are helping the war victims, that there are dozens of gang rapes on the Ukrainian territories which used to be temporarily occupied by the Russian military. This form of violence is particularly traumatic for survivors of abuse.
The war must end so that no woman or child in another country experiences the horror which we now have in Ukraine. What’s more, every war criminal must be punished. In the age of information technology, it is possible to identify and find the culprits!
That is why Ukrainians continue to fight against a country that has a much larger number of soldiers and weapons.
Support Ukraine in this struggle for peace and justice!

Russia has been expelled from the UN Human Rights Council for gross and systematic human rights abuses following the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
This is not the first time Moscow has been expelled from international organizations after its military aggression. After the annexation of the Ukrainian Crimea in 2014, Russia was excluded from the G8. Back in 1939, the USSR was expelled from the League of Nations, and Russia considers itself its successor. This happened after Soviet troops invaded Finland. The immediate reason for the exclusion of the USSR from the League of Nations was the bombing of Finnish civilian objects by Soviet aircraft. Then in Finland, as now in Ukraine, the Russians used inhumane and forbidden methods of warfare. Russia has not changed: it continues to barbarically destroy civilians in all of its wars. Russia is a country of the past, which cannot forgive other states for wanting to develop and create better living in comparison to Russia. The Russian Federation must be stopped right now!

Ukraine is a country of people who are used to creating things: they are growing, building, and producing. Ukrainians always united in communities because it’s easier to accomplish important changes together. An active civil society on the Independence Square, or Maydan, in Kyiv in 2004 and 2014 is an example of the unity that the whole world could see. Today, this unity has manifested itself in the most powerful volunteer movement in Europe. Everyone helps as much as they can: people cook, raise money, collect humanitarian aid, cover urgent needs of the army and medics, coordinate, transport, help with evacuation, write petitions, and fight against Russian propaganda. Our Post-to-stop-war project is also done by volunteers.
We want everyone to know the truth about this war so the world would act! Inaction now is a crime.
We also call on to support the Armed Forces of Ukraine and trusted volunteer organizations. All information can be found in the section of our site called How you can help Ukraine.
Join the volunteer movement of Ukraine! Help Ukrainians!

Russian mobile crematoriums started operating in Mariupol. Following the widespread international outcry after the Bucha genocide, Russia's top leadership has ordered the destruction of any evidence of Russian military atrocities in Mariupol. Given the size of the city, catastrophic destruction, the duration of the blockade, and fierce resistance, tens of thousands of civilians from Mariupol could fall victim to the Russian occupiers. To cover up the enormous scale of its crimes, Russia is preventing humanitarian initiatives in Mariupol and the complete evacuation of its inhabitants. Instead, they are trying to identify all potential witnesses to Russia's atrocities through filtration camps and kill them. Mayor Vadym Boychenko states: “The world has not seen the scale of the tragedy in Mariupol since the existence of Nazi concentration camps! The Russians turned the whole of Mariupol into a death camp. This is no longer Chechnya or Aleppo. This is the new Auschwitz and Maidanek. The world must help punish Russia's villains. " Whether the genocide perpetrated by the Russians in Ukraine will go unpunished will determine whether this evil will be repeated again, but this time, in Western Europe! Look at Russia with a sober eye! A country that emphasizes its cultural heritage and glorious history turns out to be just a brutal war criminal who tries to hide the traces of one’s terrible deeds. Remember that most Russians support the war against Ukraine. They support all the atrocities that are taking place in Ukrainian cities. This is not Putin's war, but a genocide of Ukrainians, and Russians glorify and are proud of it!

620,000 Ukrainians returned to Ukraine in a month, between February 24 to March 24. These are mostly men. They are not hiding from the war in other countries. They are ready to defend their country, but they need weapons. The world can save Ukraine if it provides the necessary weapons and helps stop Russia. Demand help from your governments!

The war in Ukraine, started by the Russians, could cause famine for 100 million people around the world. This is the finding from the experts at the University of Bonn in Germany. Russian troops are mining fields, blowing up agricultural machinery, and destroying fuel supplies in order to sabotage crop production in Ukraine.
Ukraine is one of the largest exporters of grain and sunflower oil, the bulk of which is delivered by sea. Russia imposed a naval blockade on Ukraine. Already by the end of March, Russians blocked the exit of 94 ships from the Black Sea which transported food. The Russian war will significantly reduce this year's harvest and exports.
Not only Ukraine but the whole world will suffer from the war. To stop the war, the world must impose tougher sanctions on Russia and enforce them uncompromisingly!

Russia's war against Ukraine has a significant history. After the collapse of the Soviet Union, the loss of Ukraine, one of the largest countries in Europe in terms of territory and population, became especially painful for Moscow. Since then, Russia has been constantly trying to bring Ukraine back under its influence, especially since 1999, when Putin became Russia's president. The 2004 Orange Revolution was Putin's first defeat in Ukraine. Then Viktor Yanukovych, who was actively supported by Moscow, lost the presidential election to pro-European Viktor Yushchenko. Putin's second defeat was the Revolution of Dignity. Then, Ukrainians overthrew the pro-Russian regime of President Yanukovych, one again choosing the Western direction for Ukraine's development. The full-scale war launched by the Russians on February 24, 2022, is Putin's last argument for taking control of Ukraine. But Ukrainians will fight to the end. And they will never return to the "Russian world".

The T-72 tank costs around $3 million. The T-90 tank has an estimated price of $4.5 million. Every month, Europe transfers more than 14 billion Euros to Russia, paying for its energy resources. In tank currency, we are talking about 3,000 to 4,000 tanks per month. An embargo on Russian oil and gas will save the lives of Europeans. Life is not a tank: it is priceless. Demand an embargo - save lives!

Russia establishes filtration camps and forcibly deports Ukrainians there. The Main Department of Intelligence of the Ministry of Defense of Ukraine confirms cases of kidnapping Ukrainian citizens, Ukrainian military, and police. Then the kidnapped are moved to the RF, to Taganrog (the Rostov region), and the Krasnodar region in particular. After this, their documents get confiscated, and the people are sent to the northeast of Russia. According to the Mariupol city council, about 15 thousand Mariupolites were illegally deported. It seems, deporting the population, Russia mirrors the deportation actions of the Nazi regime that ruled Europe in the middle of the 20th century.

Russian troops drop 50-100 bombs on Mariupol every day. They have destroyed 80-90% of the city. The occupiers defrauded and forcibly deported 33 thousand residents to Russia. People live in an information blockade, and many do not understand what is happening. Nobody knows how many people continue to be under the wreckage and how many were wounded or killed. People have no chance to get out of there. Russian occupants killed municipal and state service people and rescuers during the days of the blockade, so there's nobody to search the city ruins. They also killed many doctors. All the survivors of the bombing will either die under the wreckage or have already died. Tens of thousands of people are buried alive under the rubble of the city, destroyed by 80%. This is a GLOBAL tragedy! Mariupol should be on front pages of all world newspapers. All world platforms and all human rights activists should talk about Mariupol! Today Mariupol is a torture chamber where Russians kill women and children in the most brutal ways!"

Since Russia invaded Ukraine, more than 1,5 million Ukrainian children have become refugees. More than 70,000 children flee the country every day, 55 every minute. Many of those children become orphans or lose their parents and relatives. Stories about small kids crossing borders alone amaze the world and confirm the heroism of the Ukrainian nation. We are grateful to all the countries that help Ukrainian refugees. We urge them to speak up and demand the closure of airspace over Ukraine! So our children and we won't have to flee our homes, devastated by the Russian bombs.
